Like, once you get past 10 nonillion or so, the number you're talking about is so large that there is no meaningful comparison for it in the universe. q.q: on blender, assuming you are using cycles render,

q.a: trying cycles render, that is much slower and/or noisier, (about 13 seconds per frame, and still too much noise, that's at 64 samples) and the viewport is noisy/slow, that would be at 32. Eevee is much faster for both, and with eevee, the preview-viewport version displays absolutely perfectly at 16 samples, absolutely instantly, noise free. And yet, render still takes 1/2 second per frame, at 16 samples. much much better than cycles, but the mystery still persists as to what should stop me from just screenrecording the viewport for perfect instant results ....... and yet the render still needs to compute .... To push this mystery a little bit further, still on eevee, i've set the render sample rate to 1, (!!!) the render still is completely noise free and looks great, (???) and does about 3 frames per second. The viewport preview, however, i've just set to 500 samples (!!!), and it still renders absolutely instantly. ?????? it's got to be aliens
q.q: make sure in the render settings in the 'sampling' section the samples value isn't placed too high, because that value is different from the preview value. setting the value too low will add a lot of noise to the image, but setting it too high takes too long

q.a: you can try 7 or 8, but, if you are still feeling overwhelmed, don't forget that you always have the option of actually dialing it back to 1 second. the advantages here are ridiculous. you will finish it very quickly, freeing up time to do 3, 4, 5 second or more. you learn things every time you finish a song, so 1 second means almost instantaneous learning. if you are feeling frozen like you can't do anything and you're confused and can't learn anything, just try something shorter. eventually you will go from learning nothing to learning everything, extremely quickly. and then increase the length from there. it's like going up a staircase. very easy, if you actually start at the bottom

q.a: ok, 2 very important things i have to say about this. 1, yes, you can absolutely use additional keyboards with kbm, all with their own separate keys. i'm currently using 9 keyboards. i will explain the trick i discovered for doing that. but the other important thing i must tell you first is that if you start including wireless keyboards in your setup, you will be in agony city. i had 3 wireless keyboards in the setup and it was a disaster. it's occasionally annoying when a bluetooth keyboard disconnects, but if you have 4 bluetooth keyboards it's going to happen 4 times more often. actually more, because bluetooth just gets messed up when you have too many. i returned all the wireless keyboards and went for wired keyboards only. much more reliable. Ok, now that that hint/tip is out of the way, the secret for getting additional keyboards in kbm is first get Karabiner Elements (this is a key-swapping software). But instead of swapping keys, you are actually going to disable every key. (set it to "vk disable".) this may take a while if you go through the popup menus, but if you open the json file you can change it via the text all in one shot (with a little help from kbm of course). Once you have all the keys disabled, go into keyboard maestro and when you make your trigger, instead of "Hot Key" trigger, use "USB device key" trigger, press a button and it will come right up. This works for almost any keyboard you can imagine, even PC keyboards (although you may never get the function key.) Another secret tip that i will tell you is, if extra keyboards don't work when you first try, or if they don't work when you first boot up, just put the computer to sleep then wake it up. quickest way is to go to the lock screen and then unlock (and i've now zapped that with a macro). only have to do it if i restart, otherwise they work forever. it took me a while to figure that out, i thought they mysteriously just didn't work until i went to lunch. email me if you need any more tips, i have learned a lot so far, and it's a strange world, and i've run into a lot of things i didn't expect, but overall it's been much easier than i expected, considering what i've seen Tom Scott and Taran Van Hemert had to go through. and i'm not even sure if peternlewis is even aware that what i'm doing is possible

q.a: if you're feeling overwhelmed, a good catch-all solution for this is to simply start making the songs much shorter. like much shorter. 22 seconds. 12 seconds. ...... still, a lot of unknown fears can lurk even in 12 seconds, so don't be afraid to dial it back to, yep i said it, .... 4 seconds. if you can't do that, then try 3. if you think this is insane, i dare you to not have fun while writing a 2 second song. and this way you'll get to take a tour of the entire songwriting factory, instantly. your level of experience will soon double and triple, effortlessly, as easy as eating grains of rice

q.q:
Hello I realised am addicted to quite a few different things.

In order of addictiveness they are:
Nicotine (vape. every 10 minutes)
Caffeine (2-3 in the morning)
Weed (every night and all day on the weekends)
Alcohol (every night with more on the weekends)
Fapping (every night and sometimes more)
Takeaway food (5-6 times a week)

These are the main ones. No single one is ruining my life (maybe alcohol and weed a little), but the main thing is that I want to be free and natural.

Apart from weaning myself off caffeine, I plan to give them all up cold turkey at the same time for 30 days (except for Takeaway food if I am stuck some day). I can't find anything of anyone else doing similar. Do you think it's a bad idea to give up so much so quick? I am thinking of documenting my experience.

q.a: bits and pieces may come to me at any time. need to be adept at catching them, recording them, and logging them into a master list, by date. then there's the selection process, for that i usually go through the whole list and write down ones that i am excited about doing. then, when that semi-finals list is done, immediately put it through a number-randomizer to get the final selection. then, when i have the selection, i have to play doctor with it. i have to look at it and make an assessment as to what the nature of that item is, whether it is the chorus, the first verse, etc etc. ... and evaluate what it needs. things get confusing if it's not the intro, because that means i have to work backwards, which can be very tedious. but if i just hang around and ask the right questions, i can get there. once i have the beginning, then it's a little more standard. just do run throughs from the beginning, in time (at tempo, with click) and then pay very close attention to the moments right when i reach the ending edge of what's written. that's when i may or may not be struck with solutions for what follows. then, whether or not it strikes, evaluate for a minute what the implications may be, then do a re-set, which for me is touch the door, and then run it again

q.a: i'm not sure which is which, and whether the numbering you're looking for starts with 0 or 1, but here is the harmonic series, if you have a very low C (around 33hz). the next note is an octave up, (65) then the next G up (around 98) then another C (131), then something around E (around 178) that will wring perfectly in a chord with C (even better than standard E), then the next G (196) then something about halfway in between A and Bb (around 226??) (they are all getting closer together.) then C again (262) then something around D (294?) then another E which rings perfectly in harmony with C (327.5), then, this might be the one you're looking for, something that's like exactly halfway between E and G. so it will be somewhere between F and F#. 360.25. not good. then the next one is another clean G. then some more ugly in between ones. did we get to the one you want yet

q.a: step 1, make sure it's dynamic sensitive (obviously) .... then, break the kit down in a different way: consider it more like 4 instruments. 1 is kick and snare, 2 is cyms, 3 and 4 are both percussion. actually 3 through 7 should be percussion. just do all the percussion first, and you're gonna be fine. quantize at 50% strength and add just the tiniest hair of swing, even if it's considered straight. you should be good to go. if you get hung up, do a little "writing" or pre-arranging: sit in a chair like you're a drummer, and pretend you're the drummer on the song. just imagine playing through it and figure out what you did. write it down and then put it together

q.a: yes, if i can remember. the first line had been on the shelf since maybe september? [checking] october 19, 2018. it was just the first line. then when it came time to pick a song, in december, i think i narrowed it down to about 20 songs and then my mistake was that i went through those 20 and narrowed it down again, and it got narrowed down to zero. so i went back to the list of 20 and picked the one i thought was the weakest. and it was that one. then i wrote it, very fast, because i was still attempting to do the 2-week schedule at that time, but i think it had already fallen apart by then. but i think i had convinced myself of some backup plan during that time. it was a long string of failures during that time, regarding the schedule. other than that i don't remember too much about the writing process. it was pretty standard. oh here's something i remember about the writing: the 'hey, what's the name of this game, ..etc.' all of that, after i wrote that i thought it was great but not right for this song. so i spent quite a while trying to come up with a plan B for that, and save that for a different song. i was really convinced that wasn't going to work for this song, as much as i liked it. then eventually i gave into using it. after that i think the writing went pretty smoothly and quickly. the recording process went slightly slower than some of the previous songs because i was just tired of rushing. it was probably rushed until i realized i had blown whatever the latest deadline was, then i was probably a bit more meticulous after that. and the release got screwed up too, because i was aiming for a certain date with the video so i sent it to the stores 2 days before that date, but couldn't finish the video. so the song hit the stores way before the video, by mistake. it was awkward. that turned out to be what the bad thing was

q.a: whether it's time for the ending or not, the process is the same. start with a fresh mind, and play the song in real time from the beginning (at the proper tempo. use a metronome). just as you reach the end of the last known part, this is when the answers will present themselves to you. if you can, try to shut off the metronome within 4 bars of when you reach the end. pay very close attention in that moment, within 5 seconds before and after you reach the end. this is when the lightning will strike. try to gather as much as you can from that moment. then, in the following seconds after that, as the moment fades, start to analyze what you think you heard or thought of, and ask some questions to try to narrow it down. then, the only thing you can do is refresh your mind and do it again. the best way to refresh your mind on this is to not hear the song for several hours. but, not everyone has time to waste several hours between run thrus, so what i usually do is start the metronome, walk to the door and touch the door and then return and start. another productivity tip is to be threatened by villains
